refractivityÂ¶

All data and methods for estimating a chemicalâs refractivity.

thermosteam.properties.refractivity.refractive_index(CASRN, T=None, AvailableMethods=False, Method=None, full_info=True)[source]Â¶

This function handles the retrieval of a chemicalâs refractive index. Lookup is based on CASRNs. Will automatically select a data source to use if no Method is provided; returns None if the data is not available.

Function has data for approximately 4500 chemicals.

Parameters

CASRN (string) â CASRN [-]

Returns

  • RI (float) â Refractive Index on the Na D line, [-]

  • T (float, only returned if full_info == True) â Temperature at which refractive index reading was made

  • methods (list, only returned if AvailableMethods == True) â List of methods which can be used to obtain RI with the given inputs

Other Parameters

  • Method (string, optional) â A string for the method name to use, as defined by constants in RI_methods

  • AvailableMethods (bool, optional) â If True, function will determine which methods can be used to obtain RI for the desired chemical, and will return methods instead of RI

  • full_info (bool, optional) â If True, function will return the temperature at which the refractive index reading was made

Notes

Only one source is available in this function. It is:

  • âCRCâ, a compillation of Organic RI data in [1]_.

Examples

>>> refractive_index(CASRN='64-17-5')
(1.3611, 293.15)

References

1

Haynes, W.M., Thomas J. Bruno, and David R. Lide. CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 95E. Boca Raton, FL: CRC press, 2014.

thermosteam.properties.refractivity.polarizability_from_RI(RI, Vm)[source]Â¶

Returns the polarizability of a fluid given its molar volume and refractive index.

\[\alpha = \left(\frac{3}{4\pi N_A}\right) \left(\frac{n^2-1}{n^2+2}\right)V_m\]
Parameters

  • RI (float) â Refractive Index on Na D line, [-]

  • Vm (float) â Molar volume of fluid, [m^3/mol]

Returns

alpha â Polarizability [m^3]

Return type

float

Notes

This Lorentz-Lorentz-expression is most correct when van der Waals interactions dominate. Alternate conversions have been suggested. This is often expressed in units of cm^3 or Angstrom^3. To convert to these units, multiply by 1E9 or 1E30 respectively.

Examples

>>> polarizability_from_RI(1.3611, 5.8676E-5)
5.147658123614415e-30

References

1

Panuganti, Sai R., Fei Wang, Walter G. Chapman, and Francisco M. Vargas. âA Simple Method for Estimation of Dielectric Constants and Polarizabilities of Nonpolar and Slightly Polar Hydrocarbons.â International Journal of Thermophysics 37, no. 7 (June 6, 2016): 1-24. doi:10.1007/s10765-016-2075-8.

thermosteam.properties.refractivity.molar_refractivity_from_RI(RI, Vm)[source]Â¶

Returns the molar refractivity of a fluid given its molar volume and refractive index.

\[R_m = \left(\frac{n^2-1}{n^2+2}\right)V_m\]
Parameters

  • RI (float) â Refractive Index on Na D line, [-]

  • Vm (float) â Molar volume of fluid, [m^3/mol]

Returns

Rm â Molar refractivity [m^3/mol]

Return type

float

Notes

Examples

>>> molar_refractivity_from_RI(1.3611, 5.8676E-5)
1.2985217089649597e-05

References

1

Panuganti, Sai R., Fei Wang, Walter G. Chapman, and Francisco M. Vargas. âA Simple Method for Estimation of Dielectric Constants and Polarizabilities of Nonpolar and Slightly Polar Hydrocarbons.â International Journal of Thermophysics 37, no. 7 (June 6, 2016): 1-24. doi:10.1007/s10765-016-2075-8.

thermosteam.properties.refractivity.RI_from_molar_refractivity(Rm, Vm)[source]Â¶

Returns the refractive index of a fluid given its molar volume and molar refractivity.

\[RI = \sqrt{\frac{-2R_m - V_m}{R_m-V_m}}\]
Parameters

  • Rm (float) â Molar refractivity [m^3/mol]

  • Vm (float) â Molar volume of fluid, [m^3/mol]

Returns

RI â Refractive Index on Na D line, [-]

Return type

float

Notes

Examples

>>> RI_from_molar_refractivity(1.2985e-5, 5.8676E-5)
1.3610932757685672

References

1

Panuganti, Sai R., Fei Wang, Walter G. Chapman, and Francisco M. Vargas. âA Simple Method for Estimation of Dielectric Constants and Polarizabilities of Nonpolar and Slightly Polar Hydrocarbons.â International Journal of Thermophysics 37, no. 7 (June 6, 2016): 1-24. doi:10.1007/s10765-016-2075-8.
